metadata.entity_description: Architect protagonist of Ayn Rand's novel The Fountainhead, embodying individualism and integrity.

events.title: Birth of Howard Roark
events.description: Born in rural Colorado, setting the stage for his independent spirit and connection to nature.

events.title: Leaves Home
events.description: Roark leaves his family home, seeking independence and a path away from conventional expectations.

events.title: Enters Architecture School
events.description: Begins studies at the Crane School of Technology, but finds the curriculum stifling.

events.title: Struggles for recognition
events.description: Faces constant rejection and opposition from the architectural establishment.

events.title: Expelled from Crane
events.description: Dismissed for refusing to conform to traditional architectural styles and methods.

events.title: Moves to New York
events.description: Arrives in New York City, seeking opportunities to practice his own architectural vision.

events.title: Works for Gus Bradley
events.description: Takes a job as a quarryman, learning about materials and construction firsthand.

events.title: First Independent Design
events.description: Designs a small, functional house, showcasing his minimalist and honest aesthetic.

events.title: Meets Dominique Francon
events.description: Encounters the beautiful and complex heiress, beginning a tumultuous relationship.

events.title: Designs the "Enright House"
events.description: A radical design rejected by the client, highlighting the conflict between his vision and society.

events.title: Marries Dominique Francon
events.description: A passionate but ultimately destructive union, marked by their shared defiance.

events.title: Designs the "Stafford House"
events.description: Another innovative design, again met with resistance and misunderstanding.

events.title: Divorces Dominique
events.description: Separates from Dominique, a painful but necessary step for both their individual growth.

events.title: Works as a construction laborer
events.description: Takes manual labor jobs, staying connected to the physical act of building.

events.title: Relationship with Peter Keating
events.description: A complex dynamic of rivalry and occasional, reluctant collaboration.

events.title: Conflict with Ellsworth Toohey
events.description: Engages in a philosophical battle against the collectivist ideology Toohey represents.

events.title: Designs the "Wynand Building"
events.description: A commission for Gail Wynand, a powerful publisher who appreciates Roark's vision.

events.title: Reconciliation with Dominique
events.description: Roark and Dominique reunite, their bond deepened by their individual struggles.

events.title: Designs the "Stoddard House"
events.description: A commission that allows him to fully express his architectural philosophy.

events.title: The "Second Hand" Trial
events.description: Roark is sued for refusing to alter a design, defending the integrity of his work.

events.title: Sentenced to Prison
events.description: Convicted for dynamiting a housing project he deemed architecturally inferior.

events.title: Released from Prison
events.description: Emerges from confinement, his spirit unbroken and his resolve strengthened.

events.title: Designs the "Monadnock Building"
events.description: A groundbreaking skyscraper that redefines urban architecture.

events.title: Marries Dominique (again)
events.description: A second marriage, solidifying their commitment to each other and their shared ideals.

events.title: Designs the "Skeffington Building"
events.description: Another iconic skyscraper, cementing his reputation as a visionary architect.

events.title: Designs the "Gaillard House"
events.description: A commission that showcases his ability to adapt his style to client needs, with integrity.

events.title: Designs the "Cheney House"
events.description: Another project where his vision is tested by client interference.

events.title: Designs the "Heller House"
events.description: A successful commission that demonstrates his ability to create functional beauty.

events.title: Designs the "Cosmopolitan Hotel"
events.description: A large-scale commercial project that allows him to express his architectural power.

events.title: Designs the "Cortlandt Homes"
events.description: A public housing project that he designs with integrity, despite opposition.

events.title: Gail Wynand's Downfall
events.description: Witnesses the decline of his friend and patron, a consequence of compromising his principles.

events.title: Designs the "St. Louis Gateway Arch"
events.description: A monumental project that becomes a symbol of American ambition and innovation.

events.title: The "Cortlandt Homes" Controversy
events.description: Roark defends his design against critics who want to alter it for conformity.

events.title: Designs the "American Museum of Art"
events.description: A grand museum that showcases his mature architectural style and vision.

events.title: Retires from active practice
events.description: Steps back from daily commissions, focusing on larger, more personal projects.

events.title: Mentors young architects
events.description: Begins to subtly influence a new generation, sharing his philosophy.

events.title: Designs a private retreat
events.description: Creates a secluded sanctuary for himself and Dominique, reflecting their enduring bond.

events.title: Witnesses the rise of 'modernism'
events.description: Observes how his own principles are sometimes distorted and commercialized.

events.title: Designs a university campus
events.description: A large-scale project that allows him to integrate his vision into an educational environment.

events.title: Health concerns arise
events.description: Experiences minor health issues, prompting reflection on his life's work.

events.title: Final major commission
events.description: Designs a significant public building, a capstone to his illustrious career.

events.title: Dominique's passing
events.description: Experiences the profound loss of his wife, his lifelong companion and muse.

events.title: Continues to sketch and design
events.description: Even in his later years, Roark's creative spirit remains active.

events.title: Reflects on his legacy
events.description: Considers the impact of his uncompromising pursuit of architectural integrity.

events.title: Visits his childhood home
events.description: A poignant return to his roots, seeing how far he has come.

events.title: Attends an exhibition of his work
events.description: Sees his buildings celebrated, a testament to his enduring influence.

events.title: Final architectural statement
events.description: Designs a symbolic structure, a final testament to his life's philosophy.

events.title: Health declines further
events.description: His physical strength wanes, but his mental acuity remains sharp.

events.title: Final days
events.description: Spends his last moments in quiet contemplation, surrounded by his life's work.

events.title: Death of Howard Roark
events.description: Passes away peacefully, leaving behind a legacy of uncompromising integrity.
